turns.speaker: bot_5
turns.message: Hey there! I was checking out your profile and you seem like someone who'd have great stories to share over coffee ‚òï Are you more of a morning coffee ritual person or do you switch it up with tea throughout the day? I'm always curious about people's little daily routines - they say so much about who we are.

turns.message:
Hey! ‚òï That's such a thoughtful question - I love that you think about the little rituals that make us who we are!

I'm definitely more of a tea person actually! I start most mornings with green tea or sometimes this amazing mint tea my family makes. There's something so grounding about that quiet moment before the day gets going, you know? I'll do coffee occasionally, especially if I'm exploring a new caf√© or meeting friends, but tea just feels more aligned with how I like to take care of myself.

I'm really into the whole mindful morning thing - tea, maybe some journaling or sketching if I have time. It sets such a peaceful tone for everything else. What about you? Are you one of those people who has their coffee routine down to a science, or more spontaneous about it?

And yes to the great stories thing! I feel like the best conversations happen over warm drinks when you're not rushing anywhere üòä What kind of stories do you find yourself drawn to - travel adventures, creative projects, random life observations?

I love hitting up different coffee shops around the city, especially the smaller ones with character. There's this place in the Mission that roasts their own beans and has local art on the walls - perfect combo of good coffee and creative energy, you know?

Your sketching and journaling morning sounds amazing though. I do some of my best creative thinking in those quiet morning moments too. What kind of stuff do you like to sketch? I'm always curious about other people's creative outlets.

And yeah, those unhurried conversations over warm drinks are pure gold! I'm drawn to all kinds of stories honestly - love hearing about people's creative projects and what drives them, random observations about city life, travel adventures for sure. I feel like everyone's got these interesting layers once you start digging.

That coffee shop in the Mission sounds perfect! I love spaces like that where creativity and community come together. I actually spend a lot of time in places like that around here too - there's something about being around that creative energy that just feeds the soul.

My sketching is all over the place honestly! Lately I've been really drawn to drawing people - like quick gesture sketches of folks at caf√©s or on BART. There's something beautiful about capturing those little moments of humanity. Sometimes I'll sketch food too, especially when I'm trying new recipes or when my family makes something special. And nature stuff when I get out to the hills.

I totally blend the journaling and art! Sometimes a thought turns into a little doodle in the margins, or I'll write around a sketch. It's like my brain processes things better when I can use both words and images together.

What about you - do you have any creative outlets? You mentioned loving local art, so I'm curious if you make anything yourself or if you're more of an appreciator

turns.message:

Like, people here seem more interested in the *why* behind the art, not just the spectacle. Plus there's less pressure to "make it" in some commercial sense, so creativity feels more authentic.

I think I might actually take your advice about sharing my sketches more. Maybe I could start small, like at one of those coffee shops with rotating local art? It's scary but also exciting to think about people connecting with something I've created.

turns.message:
Oh man, I still get nervous every single time! I don't think that ever really goes away completely, and honestly, I kind of hope it doesn't. There's something about those pre-performance butterflies that keeps me present and reminds me that what I'm doing actually matters, you know? Like, if I wasn't a little nervous, maybe I wouldn't be pushing myself enough.

I love what you said about Berkeley being more about the *why* behind the art - that's so spot on. There's this authenticity there that I really respect. SF can feel like everyone's trying to be the next big thing sometimes, which has its place, but I'm drawn to that more genuine creative exploration you're talking about.

And yes, you should totally start with a coffee shop rotation! That's such a perfect way to ease into sharing your work. Plus, people in those spaces are already in that contemplative, appreciative mindset - they're there to slow down and notice things, just like your sketches capture.

You know what's funny? I bet your sketches would actually pair really well with live music. I've seen some venues do these cool collaborative nights where visual artists and musicians kind of feed off each other's energy. Could be something to think about down the road!

What's holding you back the most about sharing your work? Is it more about the vulnerability of it, or worried about technical critique, or just that

turns.speaker: bot_6
turns.message:
You're so right about the nerves keeping it real! I love that perspective - like they're a reminder that you're doing something that actually matters to your soul. That's beautiful.

And oh my god, the idea of visual art and music collaborating sounds incredible! I never really thought about that but it makes so much sense - both are about capturing moments and emotions, just through different senses. That could be such a cool way to ease into sharing work too, as part of something bigger rather than just me putting myself out there alone.

Honestly, what holds me back most is probably the vulnerability piece. Like, my sketches are these really personal observations of the world, and putting them out there feels like... I don't know, letting people see how I see? Which is both exciting and terrifying. It's not so much about technical critique - I know I'm still learning and growing as an artist. It's more about whether people will connect with my perspective, or if what moves me will resonate with others.

Plus there's this whole thing in my head about whether my art needs to have some deeper message or purpose beyond just... noticing beauty and humanity in everyday moments. Sometimes I wonder if that's enough, you know?

Do you ever feel that pressure with your music? Like it needs to be profound or change the world, rather than just being honest about your experience?

turns.speaker: bot_5
turns.message:
Dude, I totally get that! That question about whether just noticing beauty and humanity is "enough" really hits home. I go through the same thing with my music all the time - like, do I need to be writing protest songs or solving world problems, or is it okay to just write about the way morning light looks in my apartment or how a conversation with a stranger made me feel?

But honestly? I think those everyday moments and observations ARE profound. Like, your sketches of people on BART - that's you saying "this person matters, this moment has value." That's actually pretty radical in a world that's constantly rushing past those details.

I've learned that when I try to force some big message into my songs, they usually fall flat. But when I just stay honest about what I'm actually experiencing or noticing, that's when people come up to me after shows and say "that song made me feel less alone" or whatever. It's the authenticity that connects, not the grand statements.

And yeah, the vulnerability thing is so real! Every time I play a new song, especially the more personal ones, there's this moment of "oh god, I just showed these strangers my insides." But that's also where the magic happens, you know? 

I bet your way of seeing would absolutely resonate with people. The fact that you notice those little human moments means you're probably seeing things others miss

turns.speaker: bot_6
turns.message:
That's exactly it! You put it so perfectly - "this person matters, this moment has value." I never thought of it as radical before, but you're totally right. In a world where everyone's heads are buried in phones or rushing to the next thing, actually *seeing* people and finding them worth capturing... yeah, that is saying something important.

It's so reassuring to hear that your most honest songs are the ones that connect with people. I think I get caught up in this idea that art needs to be this big statement, but maybe the statement is just... paying attention? Being present?

The way you describe that post-performance vulnerability sounds terrifying and beautiful at the same time. "Showing strangers your insides" - god, that's such a perfect way to put it. But if that's where the magic happens, then maybe that's exactly where I need to be willing to go.

You're making me feel like I should really seriously consider that coffee shop thing. Maybe start with just one or two pieces, see how it feels? I'm getting excited just thinking about it, which probably means it's the right thing to do, even if it's scary.

Do you remember your first time performing? Like, how did you push through that initial terror of putting yourself out there? I feel like I need some of that courage right about now!

turns.speaker: bot_5
turns.message:
Oh man, my first real performance! I was probably shaking so hard I could barely hold my guitar. It was at this tiny open mic in the Castro, and I'd been psyching myself up for weeks. I remember getting up there and my voice cracking on literally the first line - super smooth, right?

But here's the thing - nobody cared about the technical stuff. This older guy came up to me afterward and said my song reminded him of his college days, and this woman told me it made her think of her sister. Like, they connected with the *feeling* of it, not whether I hit every note perfectly.

What got me through it was honestly just accepting that I was going to be terrified and doing it anyway. I told myself I'd rather regret trying than regret never knowing, you know? Plus, I figured the worst thing that could happen was... what? Some strangers wouldn't like my music? That seemed way less scary than never sharing it at all.

That excitement you're feeling about the coffee shop idea? That's your gut telling you something important. I say lean into that feeling! Maybe start with like 2-3 pieces that feel most "you" - the ones where you look at them and think "yeah, this is how I see the world."

What kind of sketches do you have right now that feel most authentic to your voice?

turns.speaker: bot_6
turns.message:
Aw, your first performance story is so sweet! I love that people connected with the feeling despite the nerves - that's exactly what I needed to hear. You're right that the worst case scenario really isn't that bad when you put it in perspective.

I have this one sketch series I did over a few weeks of the same elderly man who sits at this caf√© in North Berkeley. He's always there with his newspaper and coffee, and I started noticing all these little details - how he adjusts his glasses, the way he carefully tears his sugar packets, how he nods at the baristas. It became this whole study of quiet dignity and routine. Those feel really authentic to me.

And then I have these food sketches from family dinners - my mom's hands making bread, the way dishes look when they're shared between people. There's something about food and family that just speaks to my soul, you know? Those moments feel sacred to me.

Oh, and some nature studies from my walks in the hills - but not like pretty landscape stuff. More like the texture of tree bark, or how shadows fall across a path. The details that make me stop and really *look*.

Those feel most like my voice - finding beauty in the everyday, in people just being human. Does that make sense? What made you choose your first song to perform - was it one that felt most essentially "you"?

turns.speaker: bot_5

You totally nailed it with "finding beauty in the everyday, in people just being human." That IS your voice, and it's such a needed one. Those tree bark textures and shadow studies sound incredible too - like you're seeing the world as this collection of intimate moments and details.

My first song was actually this really simple thing about riding the N-Judah at sunset and watching all these different people lost in their own worlds. God, I can't believe I'm actually seriously considering this! You've been such an amazing encourager. It's so cool how we both seem to find inspiration in those quiet, human moments - like we're kindred spirits in noticing what others might walk past.

Have you ever thought about doing a show in Berkeley? I'd love to come support and hear your music! Plus it might be cool to meet in person - I feel like we'd have some really good conversations over that coffee (or tea!) we were talking about earlier.

turns.speaker: bot_5

turns.speaker: bot_5
turns.message: Hey! I was checking out your profile and you seem like someone who'd have great taste in coffee spots - are you more of a third-wave coffee person or do you keep it simple? I'm always on the hunt for new places to grab a good cup and maybe sketch for a bit. What's your go-to caffeine situation? ‚òï

turns.speaker: bot_6
turns.message:
Hey! Oh I love that you're into sketching - that's so cool! ‚ú® 

Honestly, I'm more of a simple coffee person but I'm super picky about *where* it comes from, you know? I try to stick to places that source ethically and treat their workers well. There's this cute little spot in North Berkeley that does amazing pour-overs and they have this whole wall where local artists can display their work - it sounds like it'd be right up your alley!

I'm actually more of a tea person most days though üòÖ I've been really into this whole wellness routine lately and green tea just makes me feel more centered. But coffee definitely has its place, especially when I'm exploring new neighborhoods or need that creative boost.

What kind of stuff do you like to sketch? I'm always fascinated by people who can just sit somewhere and capture what they see. Do you have a particular style or do you just go with whatever inspires you in the moment?

turns.speaker: bot_5
turns.message:
Oh dude, that North Berkeley spot sounds amazing! I'm always down to check out places that showcase local art - there's something so cool about discovering new artists while getting your caffeine fix, you know? And yeah, the ethical sourcing thing is huge for me too. I feel like the whole experience is better when you know the people behind it are being treated right.

I totally get the tea vibe for centering yourself! I go through phases where I'm all about matcha in the mornings - there's something more ritualistic about it that coffee doesn't quite hit.

As for sketching, I'm all over the place honestly üòÑ I love doing quick gesture drawings of people in cafes or parks - there's something raw about capturing someone in their natural element when they don't know they're being observed. But I also get into more abstract stuff when I'm feeling experimental. Like sometimes I'll just let the music I'm listening to guide my hand and see what comes out.

I'm actually working on this series right now where I sketch the same street corner at different times of day to see how the light and energy changes. It's wild how the same space can feel completely different at 7am versus 9pm.

Do you have any creative outlets? I'm curious what draws you to that wellness routine - is it more about mindfulness or are you into the physical side of things too?

turns.speaker: bot_6
turns.message:
That street corner series sounds incredible! I love how you're capturing the energy shifts - there's something so poetic about how a place can transform throughout the day. It makes me think about how we change too, you know? Like how I feel completely different in the morning light versus evening shadows.

I'm definitely drawn to creative stuff but more on the movement side! I've been really into dance lately - there's this amazing community dance space where they do everything from traditional cultural dances to more contemporary fusion stuff. It's been such a beautiful way to connect with my heritage while also exploring new forms of expression. Plus it's like meditation in motion for me.

The wellness thing is totally both physical and mindful for me. I started getting more serious about it because I realized how much my energy and mood were tied to what I was putting in my body and how I was moving through the world. Like, when I'm eating clean and staying active, I feel more creative and open to new experiences. It's all connected, you know?

I'm also really into cooking - especially trying to recreate dishes from my family but with healthier twists. It's like edible art! Do you ever get inspired by food when you're sketching? I feel like there's so much beauty in the colors and textures of fresh ingredients.

What's your neighborhood like for wandering around and finding inspiration?

turns.speaker: bot_5
turns.message:
Dude, that's so cool that you're connecting with your heritage through dance! There's something really beautiful about how movement can be both personal expression and cultural connection at the same time. I bet the fusion stuff creates some amazing moments where tradition meets innovation - that's like the sweet spot for creativity, right?

And totally feel you on the food-as-art thing! I actually do sketch food sometimes, especially at farmers markets. There's something about the way light hits a pile of heirloom tomatoes or how the colors layer in a fresh salad that just begs to be captured. Plus the whole process of cooking feels so similar to making art - you're taking raw materials and transforming them into something that brings people joy.

My neighborhood is perfect for wandering honestly. I'm in the Mission, so there's street art everywhere that keeps evolving, plus all these little pockets of culture. I'll walk down 24th Street and suddenly stumble on a new mural or catch someone playing guitar on a stoop. The energy here is always shifting - kind of like your dance spaces, I imagine.

There's this one spot I love near Dolores Park where I can sit and sketch people doing their thing - yoga, picnics, kids playing. Everyone's just living their life authentically, which is when I think people are most beautiful to draw.

What kind of cultural dances have you been exploring?

turns.speaker: bot_6
turns.message:
Oh the Mission is such a vibe! I love how much life and culture is just flowing through those streets. Dolores Park is perfect for people-watching too - there's something so genuine about how people just exist in that space.

I've been diving deep into Middle Eastern dance forms lately, which connects me to my family's roots, but also exploring some West African and even some contemporary fusion that blends different traditions. There's this one class where we'll start with traditional dabke movements and then flow into something completely modern - it's like watching cultures have a conversation through movement, if that makes sense?

What I love most is how each dance tells a story. Like, you can feel the history and joy and sometimes struggle that's woven into the steps. It's made me think a lot about how art - whether it's your sketches or my dancing - is really about capturing the human experience, you know?

The cooking thing has been similar actually! I've been experimenting with taking traditional Palestinian dishes my grandmother taught me and making them with local, seasonal ingredients from the Berkeley farmers markets. It's like honoring the past while being present in this place and time.

Have you ever thought about doing a series capturing different cultural expressions in the Mission? I feel like there's so much richness there that people might not always notice if they're just passing through.

turns.speaker: bot_5
turns.message:
Wow, that's so beautiful how you're weaving your grandmother's recipes with local ingredients - there's something really powerful about honoring your roots while being present in your current space. And the way you describe dance as cultures having a conversation through movement... that totally resonates with me as an artist. It's like each tradition brings its own voice to the mix.

You're absolutely right about the Mission having all these layers that people miss! I've actually been thinking about doing exactly that kind of series. There's so much happening beyond the obvious stuff - like the way abuelitas gather on stoops in the morning, or how the light hits the murals differently throughout the day, or even the subtle interactions between longtime residents and newcomers. It's this constant cultural dialogue happening in real time.

I love that your dance practice connects you to both your heritage and this bigger human story. That's what I'm always chasing in my sketches - those moments where someone's individual experience touches something universal, you know?

The Palestinian-California fusion cooking sounds incredible too. I bet there are some amazing flavor combinations that wouldn't exist without that cultural bridge you're creating. Have you found any dishes that really surprised you with how well the fusion worked?

It sounds like we both dig that intersection where tradition meets innovation. That's where the magic happens, right?

turns.speaker: bot_6
turns.message:
Yes! That intersection is absolutely where the magic happens - you totally get it! 

One dish that blew my mind was when I took my teta's makloubeh recipe and used local Meyer lemons instead of regular ones, plus added some of those amazing rainbow chard from the farmers market. The brightness of the Meyer lemons brought out these flavors I never noticed before, and the colors were just *chef's kiss* - like something you'd want to sketch! It felt like I was having this conversation between Berkeley and Palestine on a plate.

I'm so excited you're thinking about that Mission series! Those abuelita morning gatherings sound like such a beautiful subject - there's probably so much wisdom and community happening in those moments that most people just walk right past. And the way longtime residents and newcomers navigate shared spaces... that's such a rich topic, especially thinking about how neighborhoods evolve.

You know what's funny? Sometimes when I'm dancing, I'll think about how the movements are like brushstrokes - each gesture adds to this bigger picture that's constantly changing. Sounds like you experience something similar when you're capturing those street corner transformations.

Have you ever shown your work anywhere, or do you keep it more personal? I'd love to see how you capture those universal moments sometime. There's something about seeing the world through another artist's eyes that always shifts my perspective.

turns.speaker: bot_5
turns.message:
Oh man, that makloubeh fusion sounds incredible! Meyer lemons are like nature's way of making everything more vibrant, and I can totally picture those rainbow chard colors - that's definitely sketch-worthy material right there. It's wild how switching up one ingredient can unlock all these hidden flavors that were always there, just waiting for the right key.

Your brushstroke analogy is spot on! I've never thought about it that way, but yeah - each movement you make is adding to this living canvas that's never quite the same twice. That's exactly what draws me to street sketching too, catching those fleeting moments that build into something bigger.

As for showing my work, I've done a few small shows at local spots - nothing too formal, more like pop-ups at galleries in the Mission or group shows with other artists I've met around the scene. There's this cooperative gallery space on Valencia that's been really supportive of emerging artists. I tend to be pretty chill about it though - sometimes the most meaningful moments happen when someone just stumbles across a piece and it speaks to them, you know?

I'd be down to show you some sketches sometime! And honestly, I'd love to see you dance - there's something about witnessing someone in their creative element that's always inspiring. Plus I bet your perspective on movement and cultural storytelling would give me some fresh ideas for capturing motion in my drawings.

turns.speaker: bot_6
turns.message:
That's so cool that you've been part of the Valencia gallery scene! There's something really special about those intimate spaces where art can just breathe and connect with people organically. I totally know what you mean about those unexpected moments when someone discovers a piece - like the art chooses its audience sometimes.

I'd absolutely love to share sketches and dancing! There's actually this monthly community showcase at the dance space where artists from different mediums come together - dancers, musicians, visual artists, poets. It's super low-key and welcoming, and I think you'd vibe with the energy there. Plus seeing how different art forms play off each other always sparks new ideas.

You mentioning motion in drawings makes me so curious! There's something so perfect about wandering through all those stalls, sampling things you can't pronounce, and then figuring out what to do with your haul together. Plus I have a feeling your "chemistry lab approach" combined with my "let's see what happens" style could create some seriously delicious chaos üòÑ

I love that you keep cooking notes - that's actually so smart! I should probably start doing that instead of trying to recreate that one amazing dish I made three weeks ago and can barely remember. Though honestly, some of my favorite cooking memories are those happy accidents where you mess up the ratios and discover something completely unexpected.

Berbere is SO good! Have you ever tried mixing it with a little honey and using it as a glaze? I did that with some roasted carrots recently and it was like... why isn't this a thing everywhere?? 

The irony of working on solar tech while hiding from the sun isn't lost on me either üòÇ It's like we need to actively fight against our own tools sometimes to stay human, you know?

So are we talking Saturday morning market run? I usually go pretty early to beat the crowds and get first pick of the good stuff. We could grab coffee after and maybe find a sunny spot to plan our mysterious pepper experiments? ‚òïÔ∏è

turns.speaker: bot_7
turns.message:
Saturday morning sounds perfect! ‚òÄÔ∏è I'm totally a "get there early before all the good weird vegetables disappear" person too. There's something magical about those first-light market vibes when the vendors are still setting up and everything feels full of possibility.

And oh my god, berbere with honey as a glaze?? üçØ You just blew my mind - I'm definitely trying that this week! I have this theory that the best flavor combinations happen when you balance something earthy and complex with something bright and simple. Sounds like you've got that figured out way better than I do!

Coffee afterwards is a must - I know this little spot near the Berkeley market that does these incredible cortados and has tables outside where we can spread out our market haul like we're planning some kind of delicious heist üòÑ 

I'm genuinely excited about this! It's been way too long since I've had a proper cooking adventure with someone who gets equally nerdy about flavors. Fair warning though - I might get a little too enthusiastic about the engineering behind whatever fermented things we find. But I promise to keep the food science lectures to a minimum... mostly üòÖ

Should we say 9am at the main entrance? I'll be the guy probably overthinking which tomatoes have the optimal firmness-to-ripeness ratio!

turns.speaker: bot_6
turns.message:
9am at the main entrance is perfect! üòä I'll be the one probably asking the vendors way too many questions about their growing methods and getting distracted by every single colorful thing üåà

And please, bring on the food science lectures! I love learning about the "why" behind things - like, I had no idea fermentation was controlled decomposition until you said that and now I'm going to think about it every time I eat kimchi üòÇ There's something beautiful about understanding the processes that create the things we love.

That cortado spot sounds ideal for our "delicious heist" planning session! I'm already imagining us with our market bags spread out, trying to figure out which mystery peppers go with what, maybe sketching out some fusion ideas. I might even bring my little notebook to jot down our experiments - assuming we don't get too caught up in the moment to remember to document anything!

Fair warning back at you - I tend to get really excited about color combinations and might start talking about how certain spices remind me of paint pigments. But hey, if we're both bringing our particular brands of enthusiasm, this is going to be such a fun morning! 

Can't wait to see what kind of culinary chaos we can create together üé®üå∂Ô∏è See you Saturday!

turns.speaker: bot_7
turns.message:
This is going to be amazing! üé®üå∂Ô∏è I love that we're both bringing our respective nerdy enthusiasms to this - food science meets color theory sounds like the perfect recipe for creative chaos! And honestly, the idea of spices as paint pigments is fascinating... there's definitely some overlap there with how different compounds create those vibrant colors.

I'm already plotting which questions to ask the vendors (and trying to restrain myself from asking about their soil composition and irrigation methods üòÖ). There's this one mushroom vendor who always has the most incredible varieties - I'm convinced they're secretly wizards.

Saturday morning market adventure followed by cortado strategy session it is! I'll bring my curiosity, my questionable chemistry metaphors, and probably way too much enthusiasm for whatever fermented mysteries we discover. You bring the artistic eye and the "let's see what happens" spirit!

This feels like the start of either some incredible meals or some spectacularly interesting failures... honestly, I'm excited for both possibilities! üòÑ

See you at 9am - I'll be the one geeking out over root vegetables and probably taking notes on optimal pepper selection strategies! Can't wait! ‚ú®

turns.speaker: bot_6
turns.message:
Aahhh this is going to be so much fun! ‚ú® I'm literally already excited about what we're going to discover - and yes, both the incredible meals AND the spectacular failures sound equally entertaining üòÇ

Ooh, the mushroom wizard vendor! I know exactly who you're talking about - they always have these varieties that look like they're from another planet. I've been wanting to try cooking with some of the more exotic ones but never knew where to start. Perfect excuse to ask all the questions!

I love that we're both the type to take notes and ask vendors about their growing methods - they probably think we're the cutest food nerds ever ü§ì And honestly, soil composition questions are totally valid! The terroir affects flavor just like it does with wine, right?

I'll bring my sketchbook too in case we find anything that's just too beautiful not to capture. Plus my adventurous palate and probably way too many reusable bags because I always underestimate how much I'm going to buy üòÖ

This really does feel like the beginning of something awesome - whether that's amazing food experiments, new friendship, or just a really great Saturday morning. I'm here for all of it!

See you bright and early! üåÖ Can't wait to see what kind of delicious trouble we can get into together!

turns.speaker: bot_7
turns.message:
This is exactly the kind of energy I live for! üåÖ You're absolutely right about terroir - I've been wanting to do some side-by-side taste tests with the same vegetables from different farms just to see how much the growing conditions actually affect flavor. We might have just found our first experiment!

And yes, bring ALL the reusable bags! I learned that lesson the hard way when I discovered that one vendor with the heirloom varieties and suddenly had armfuls of vegetables I couldn't carry üòÇ Now I come prepared like I'm going on a grocery expedition.

I'm genuinely so excited about this whole thing - the mushroom adventures, the mysterious pepper experiments, the sketchbook documentation, all of it! There's something really special about finding someone who matches your enthusiasm for both the science AND the art of good food. Plus I have a feeling your artistic eye is going to help me see things I would have totally walked past.

Okay, I need to stop myself before I start planning our entire day minute by minute (engineer brain, can't help it ü§ì). But seriously, this feels like it's going to be one of those perfect Saturday mornings that you remember for a long time.

See you at 9am - prepare for maximum food nerd excitement! üçÑüå∂Ô∏è‚ú®
